title: Sleep disorders - shift work and jet lag
content: Shift work disorder and jet lag are both circadian rhythm sleep disorders (CRSDs).

title: Otitis media - acute
content: Acute otitis media (AOM) is inflammation in the middle ear associated with an effusion, and accompanied by the rapid onset of ear infection

title: Multimorbidity
content: Multimorbidity is two or more long-term health conditions

title: Pubic lice
content: Pubic lice infestation is caused by the louse Phthirus pubis.Pubic lice are blood-sucking insects, and are obligate parasites of humans.

title: Hypercholesterolaemia - familial
content: Familial hypercholesterolaemia (FH) is characterized by a high cholesterol concentration in the blood.

title: Earwax
content: Earwax is a normal physiological substance which is a combination of dead flattened cells, cerumen (a wax-like substance), sebum

title: Allergic rhinitis
content: Allergic rhinitis is an inflammatory disorder of the nose which occurs when the membranes lining the nose become sensitized to allergens.

title: Plantar fasciitis
content: Plantar fasciitis is a condition in which there is persistent foot pain associated with chronic degenerative and reparative processes

title: Cows' milk protein allergy in children
content: Cows' milk protein allergy is an immune-mediated allergic response to proteins in milk.It is one of the most common childhood food allergies

title: Otitis media - chronic suppurative
content: Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is a chronic inflammation of the middle ear and mastoid cavity

title: Ankylosing spondylitis
content: Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory rheumatic disease of unknown cause and varying clinical presentation.

title: Depression in children
content: The prevalence of childhood depression has been estimated to be 1% in pre-pubertal children and around 3% in post-pubertal young people.

title: Impetigo
content: Impetigo is a common contagious pyogenic infection of the superficial layers of the skin, usually caused by Staphylococcus aureus

title: Neutropenic sepsis
content: Neutropenic sepsis is a major cause of death in people with neutropenia. It is a time-critical medical emergency

title: Otitis externa
content: Otitis externa is inflammation of the external ear canal and is classified as acute - lasting 3 weeks or less or chronic - lasting longer than 3 months

title: Fungal skin infection - body and groin
content: Fungal infection of the skin (also known as ringworm or tinea) is caused by dermatophytes.

title: MI - secondary prevention
content: Myocardial infarction (MI), colloquially known as a heart attack, is necrosis of myocardial tissue due to ischaemia.

title: Molluscum contagiosum
content: Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV), a type of Poxvirus.

title: Boils, carbuncles, and staphylococcal carriage
content: A boil is a deep inflammatory nodule with walled-off purulent material, arising from a hair follicle.

title: Tennis elbow
content: Tennis elbow or lateral epicondylitis describes a tendinosis that affects the common attachment of the common extensor origin.

title: Haematospermia
content: Haematospermia is the visible presence of blood in the semen.

title: Itch in pregnancy
content: Itch in pregnancy may be caused by a pre-existing condition, or a condition specific to pregnancy.

title: Conduct disorders in children and young people
content: The term 'conduct disorders' is an overarching term used to describe conduct disorder and oppositional defiant disorder.

title: Cerebral palsy
content: Cerebral palsy is a neurological condition which affects movement and co-ordination, caused by a problem with the brain that occurs before, during or soon after birth.

title: Miscarriage
content: Miscarriage is the spontaneous loss of a pregnancy before 24 weeks' gestation. Recurrent miscarriage is the consecutive loss of three pregnancies

title: Fungal skin infection - scalp
content: Fungal infection of the scalp (scalp ringworm or tinea capitis) is caused by dermatophytes and is most common among prepubescent children.

title: Generalized anxiety disorder
content: Generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) is disproportionate, pervasive, uncontrollable, and widespread worry and a range of somatic, cognitive symptoms

title: Otitis media with effusion
content: Otitis media with effusion (OME), also known as 'glue ear', is characterized by a collection of fluid within the middle ear space

title: Contraception - IUS/IUD
content: Intrauterine contraceptives (IUCs) are long-acting reversible contraceptives (LARCs) which have a licensed duration of use of 3–10 years

title: Prostate cancer
content: Prostate cancer is a malignant tumour of the prostate. Almost all cancers of the prostate (95%) are adenocarcinomas.

title: Immunizations - travel
content: Many diseases are endemic in many regions of the world. All travellers should be up to date with routinely recommended vaccinations

title: Headache - cluster
content: Cluster headache is a rare but severe primary headache disorder — it is the most common trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia.

title: Chilblains
content: Chilblains (also known as perniosis or pernio) are localized inflammatory skin lesions on exposed extremities of the body, precipitated by cold.

title: Meniere's disease
content: Meniere's disease is a disorder affecting the inner ear which can affect balance and hearing.

title: Dry eye syndrome
content: Dry eye syndrome is a chronic condition characterised by inflammation of the ocular surface and reduction in quality and/or quantity of tears.

title: Candida - female genital
content: Vulvovaginal candidiasis (genital thrush) is a symptomatic inflammation of the vagina and/or vulva caused by a superficial fungal infection.

title: Constipation in children
content: Constipation is a decrease in the frequency of bowel movements characterized by the passing of hardened stools

title: Opioid dependence
content: All opioids have dependence potential to varying degrees. Heroin  has the greatest potential for dependency. It can develop within 2–10 days of use.

title: Depression
content: Depression is characterised by persistent low mood and/or loss of pleasure in most activities and a range of associated emotional, cognitive, physical

title: Blepharitis
content: Blepharitis describes inflammation of the margin of the eyelids.

title: Sciatica (lumbar radiculopathy)
content: Sciatica is the term for symptoms of pain, tingling, and numbness which arise from nerve root compression or irritation in the lumbosacral spine.

title: Bites - human and animal
content: Human bites are either:Occlusal injuries (inflicted by actual biting), or clenched-fist injuries - sustained when a clenched fist hits a person's teeth

title: Headache - tension-type
content: Tension-type headache is a common primary headache disorder

title: Tiredness/fatigue in adults
content: Tiredness (or fatigue) is often described as a lack of, or decreased, energy, and physical or mental exhaustion.

title: Head injury
content: Each year, 1.4 million people attend emergency departments in England and Wales with a recent head injury

title: HIV infection and AIDS
content: The Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) is a retrovirus that infects and destroys cells of the immune system, in particular CD4 cells

title: Dementia
content: Dementia is a clinical syndrome of deterioration in mental function which interferes with activities of daily living (ADLs).

title: Sinusitis
content: Sinusitis is defined as inflammation of the mucosal lining of the paranasal sinuses.

title: Colic - infantile
content: Infantile colic is a self-limiting condition which is defined clinically as repeated episodes of excessive and inconsolable crying in an infant

title: Bronchiectasis
content: Bronchiectasis is a permanent dilatation and thickening of the airways associated with chronic cough, sputum production, bacterial colonization

title: Conjunctivitis - allergic
content: Allergic conjunctivitis is a term used to describe a group of ocular conditions associated with an immunoglobulin E (IgE) hypersensitivity reaction

title: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
content: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) refers to excess triglyceride accumulation in the liver (steatosis), in the absence of excessive alcohol

title: Anal fissure
content: An anal fissure is a tear or ulcer in the lining of the anal canal, immediately within the anal margin.

title: Shingles
content: Shingles (herpes zoster) is a viral infection of nerve cells that occurs when a latent infection with varicella-zoster virus reactivates.

title: Asthma
content: Asthma is a chronic inflammatory condition of the airways.The airways are hyper-responsive and constrict easily in response to a wide range of stimuli

title: Lung and pleural cancers - recognition and referral
content: Over 43,000 new lung cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK. A full time GP is likely to diagnose approximately 1 person with lung cancer each year

title: Olecranon bursitis
content: The olecranon bursa is a sac overlying the olecranon process of the elbow beneath the skin.

title: Ovarian cancer
content: The lifetime risk of a woman being diagnosed with ovarian cancer is 1 in 48.The risk of ovarian cancer is increased by:Increasing age.

title: Irritable bowel syndrome
content: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a chronic, relapsing, and often lifelong disorder of the lower gastrointestinal tract, with no structural cause

title: Temporomandibular disorders (TMDs)
content: Temporomandibular disorders are a group of conditions affecting the masticatory muscles, the temporomandibular joint and associated structures.

title: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo
content: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is a disorder of the inner ear characterized by repeated episodes of positional vertigo

title: Corneal superficial injury
content: Superficial corneal injuries are non-penetrating injuries affecting the outermost layer of the cornea.

title: Alopecia areata
content: Alopecia areata is a chronic, inflammatory, usually relapsing condition which affects the hair follicles (and which may also affect the nails).

title: Breast pain - cyclical
content: Cyclical breast pain is related to the menstrual cycle and is not associated with specific underlying breast disease.

title: Jaundice in adults
content: Jaundice is a clinical sign describing yellow pigmentation of the skin, sclera, and mucous membranes due to raised plasma bilirubin.

title: Warts - anogenital
content: Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata) are benign, proliferative growths occurring in the genital, perineal, anal, and perianal areas.

title: Rubella
content: Rubella (also known as German measles) is an infection caused by viruses of the genus Rubivirus of the family Togaviradae.

title: Palliative cancer care - pain
content: Cancer-related pain may be persistent or breakthrough (episodic), and influenced by physical, psychological, social and spiritual factors.

title: Greater trochanteric pain syndrome (trochanteric bursitis)
content: Greater trochanteric pain syndrome is a regional pain syndrome in which chronic intermittent pain is felt around the greater trochanter

title: Head and neck cancers - recognition and referral
content: Laryngeal cancerOver 2,000 new laryngeal cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK.Five year survival is 70%.

title: Palliative care - nausea and vomiting
content: Nausea is an unpleasant sensation of the need to vomit, which is often accompanied by autonomic symptoms, for example pallor, cold sweat, salivation

title: Contraception - assessment
content: An assessment should be carried out on all women requesting contraception to identify any relevant medical conditions or medication

title: Benzodiazepine and z-drug withdrawal
content: Benzodiazepines are gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptor agonists which have hypnotic, anxiolytic, anticonvulsant, and muscle relaxant properties.

title: Fungal skin infection - foot
content: Fungal infection of the foot (athlete's foot or tinea pedis) is a skin infection of the feet and toes, predominantly caused by dermatophytes

title: Contraception - natural family planning
content: Natural family planning is a method of birth control where a woman monitors and records different fertility indicators during her menstrual cycle

title: Neuropathic pain - drug treatment
content: Neuropathic pain is a symptom that develops as a result of damage to, or dysfunction of, the nervous system.

title: Childhood cancers - recognition and referral
content: Brain and central nervous system cancers.Consider a very urgent referral for suspected brain or central nervous system

title: Pre-conception - advice and management
content: The goal of pre-conception care is to improve the long and short-term health outcomes of women and their children.

title: Dyspepsia - proven functional
content: The term 'dyspepsia' is used to describe a complex of upper gastrointestinal tract symptoms

title: Gilbert's syndrome
content: Gilbert's syndrome is an inherited (usually autosomal recessive) metabolic disorder that causes intermittent, isolated raised unconjugated bilirubin

title: Breathlessness
content: Breathlessness is a subjective, distressing sensation of awareness of difficulty with breathing.

title: Appendicitis
content: Appendicitis is an acute inflammation of the appendix, which is a small, narrow tube (about 5–10 cm) that is connected to the caecum

title: Obsessive-compulsive disorder
content: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is characterized by recurrent obsessional thoughts or compulsive acts or, commonly, both.

title: Malaria
content: Malaria is a life-threatening illness caused by infection of red blood cells by Plasmodium parasites.

title: Dyspepsia - proven peptic ulcer
content: The term 'dyspepsia' is used to describe a complex of upper gastrointestinal tract symptoms

title: Thrombophlebitis - superficial
content: Superficial thrombophlebitis is a common disorder that occurs when a superficial vein becomes inflamed (phlebitis) and the blood within it clots.

title: DVT prevention for travellers
content: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) can occur as a result of long distance travel. The risk of travel-related DVT in healthy people is extremely low

title: Tamoxifen - managing adverse effects
content: Tamoxifen is an anti-oestrogen drug licensed for the treatment of breast cancer and anovulatory infertility.

title: Herpes simplex - ocular
content: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) ocular infections can cause inflammation of the retina (retinitis), iris and associated uveal tract (iritis or uveitis)

title: Squint in children
content: A squint (strabismus) is present when one eye is misaligned in relation to the other.

title: Jaundice in the newborn
content: Jaundice is a yellow colouration of the skin and sclerae (whites of the eyes) caused by the accumulation of bilirubin, a bile pigment

title: Parvovirus B19 infection
content: Parvovirus B19 infection may cause slapped cheek syndrome (erythema infectiosum or fifth disease), commonly in school-age children.

title: Headache - assessment
content: Headache is a common symptom associated with many conditions.

title: Glaucoma
content: Glaucoma is a group of eye diseases that cause progressive optic neuropathy.Glaucoma is commonly associated with raised intraocular pressure (IOP)

title: Fibroids
content: Uterine fibroids are the most common benign tumour in women — they are a mixture of smooth muscle cells and fibroblasts,

title: Itch - widespread
content: Itch (also known as pruritus) can be defined as a sensation that elicits a desire to scratch.

title: Menorrhagia
content: Menorrhagia is excessive (heavy) menstrual blood loss which occurs regularly (every 24 to 35 days)

title: Angio-oedema and anaphylaxis
content: Angio-oedema is swelling of deep dermis, subcutaneous, or submucosal tissue, often affecting the face, genitalia, hands, or feet.

title: Post-herpetic neuralgia
content: Post-herpetic neuralgia occurs when the pain associated with shingles becomes chronic.Symptoms include constant or intermittent stabbing or burning

title: Warts and verrucae
content: Warts are small, rough growths which are caused by certain strains of the human papilloma virus (HPV).

title: Palpitations
content: Palpitations are an abnormally perceived heartbeat including a feeling of the heart racing, an irregularity, or pounding sensation

title: Hyperthyroidism
content: Hyperthyroidism occurs when an excess of circulating thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis) is produced by an overactive thyroid gland.

title: Pyelonephritis - acute
content: Acute pyelonephritis is caused by infection within the renal pelvis, with or without active infection of the renal parenchyma.

title: Palliative care - secretions
content: During the terminal phase of a person's illness, airway secretions may accumulate and result in gurgling and rattling noises during breathing

title: Styes (hordeola)
content: A stye is an acute, localized infection or inflammation of the eyelid margin, and typically presents as a painful, localized eyelid swelling.

title: Candida - skin
content: Candida is a yeast-like fungus which is part of the normal commensal flora of the human gastrointestinal tract and the vagina.

title: Varicocele
content: A varicocele is a scrotal swelling consisting of a collection of dilated veins of the pampiniform plexus in the spermatic cord.

title: Post-traumatic stress disorder
content: Post-traumatic stress disorder can develop following a major traumatic event. It can affect people of all ages.

title: Chest infections - adult
content: Acute bronchitis and community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

title: Chickenpox
content: Chickenpox is an acute disease, predominantly occurring in childhood. It is caused by varicella-zoster virus and is characterized by a vesicular rash

title: Gonorrhoea
content: Gonorrhoea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

title: Red eye
content: Serious and potentially sight-threatening causes of red eye include: Acute glaucoma, Corneal ulcer, corneal foreign body, Anterior uveitis, Scleritis.

title: Leg ulcer - venous
content: A leg ulcer is defined as the loss of skin below the knee on the leg or foot, which takes more than 2 weeks to heal.

title: Urological cancers - recognition and referral
content: Prostate cancer - over 41,000 new prostate cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK.

title: Epistaxis (nosebleeds)
content: Epistaxis is bleeding from the nose, caused by damage to the blood vessels of the nasal mucosa.Most epistaxis is self-limiting and harmless

title: Hepatitis B
content: Hepatitis B is an infectious disease of the liver caused by the hepatitis B virus.

title: Herpes simplex - genital
content: Genital herpes simplex is a sexually transmitted infection (STI), caused by infection with herpes simplex virus (HSV) 1 or HSV-2

title: Domestic violence and abuse
content: Domestic violence and abuse is a serious and common problem

title: Urinary tract infection - children
content: Urinary tract infection (UTI) is illness caused by micro-organisms in the urinary tract.

title: Achilles tendinopathy
content: Achilles tendinopathy is a soft tissue disorder which causes pain, stiffness, and swelling of the Achilles tendon.

title: Pre-patellar bursitis
content: The pre-patellar bursa lies between the anterior surface of the patella and the skin. It facilitates free movement of the skin over the patella

title: Hepatitis C
content: Hepatitis C is a slow, progressive disease of the liver caused by infection with the blood-borne hepatitis C virus (HCV).

title: Hyponatraemia
content: Hyponatraemia is defined as a serum sodium concentration of less than 135 mmol/L. It is the most commonly encountered electrolyte disorder

title: Palliative care - cough
content: Cough is a defensive reflex that occurs in response to stimulation of irritant receptors which are found in the airways.

title: Cardiac arrest - out of hospital care
content: Cardiac arrest should be diagnosed if a person is unresponsive and not breathing normally.

title: Acute kidney injury
content: The causes of acute kidney injury can be divided into pre-renal, intrinsic renal and post-renal causes.

title: Hepatitis A
content: Hepatitis A is inflammation of the liver caused by infection with the hepatitis A virus, and transmission is by the faecal-oral route.

title: Palliative care - malignant skin ulcer
content: A malignant ulcer is a proliferative or cavitating primary or secondary cancer in the skin.It may appear as a crater-like wound, a nodular 'fungus'

title: Common cold
content: The common cold is the conventional term used to describe a mild, self-limiting, viral, upper respiratory tract infection

title: Carpal tunnel syndrome
content: Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is a collection of symptoms and signs caused by compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel at the wrist.

title: Multiple sclerosis
content: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a presumed autoimmune inflammatory condition of the central nervous system (CNS) resulting in areas of demyelination

title: NSAIDs - prescribing issues
content: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) inhibit cyclo-oxygenase (COX) enzymes

title: Developmental rheumatology in children
content: Musculoskeletal problems are a common cause of visits to primary care. Many of these are for children who are healthy. This topic covers normal and red flag presentations.

title: Uveitis
content: Uveitis (also known as iritis) is inflammation of the uveal tract (iris, ciliary body, and choroid).

title: Neck pain - non-specific
content: Simple (or non-specific) neck pain is neck pain for which no specific cause can be found.

title: Palliative care - constipation
content: Constipation is defecation that is unsatisfactory because of infrequent stools, difficult stool passage, or seemingly incomplete defecation.

title: Herpes simplex - oral
content: Oral herpes simplex virus (HSV) usually causes a mild, self-limiting infection of the lips, cheeks, nose or oropharynx

title: Haemorrhoids
content: Haemorrhoids (also known as piles) are abnormally swollen vascular mucosal cushions that are present in the anal canal.

title: Diarrhoea - antibiotic associated
content: Diarrhoea is a common consequence of treatment with antibiotics, occurring in 2–25% of people taking antibiotics

title: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder
content: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a behavioural syndrome characterized by hyperactivity, impulsivity, and inattention.

title: Stroke and TIA
content: Stroke is a clinical syndrome characterised by sudden onset of rapidly developing focal or global neurological disturbance

title: Delirium
content: Delirium (sometimes called 'acute confusional state') is an acute, fluctuating syndrome of inattention, impaired level of consciousness

title: Croup
content: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is a common childhood disease that is usually caused by a virus.

title: Immunizations - pneumococcal
content: Infection with the encapsulated bacteriumStreptococcus pneumoniaecauses pneumococcal infection, which may be invasive

title: Seborrhoeic dermatitis
content: Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common inflammation of the skin occurring in areas rich in sebaceous glands

title: Eczema - atopic
content: Atopic eczema is a chronic, itchy, inflammatory skin condition that affects people of all ages, although it presents most frequently in childhood.

title: Contraception - sterilization
content: Sterilization is a form of contraception that permanently prevents a woman from getting pregnant.The operation to sterilize a man is vasectomy.

title: Ulcerative colitis
content: Ulcerative colitis is a chronic, unpredictable, relapsing–remitting, non-infectious inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract.

title: Pulmonary embolism
content: Pulmonary embolism is a condition in which one or more emboli, usually arising from a blood clot formed in the veins (or, rarely, in the right heart)

title: Paronychia - acute
content: An acute paronychia is a localized, superficial infection or abscess of the lateral and proximal skin fold around a nail (perionychium)

title: Hirsutism
content: Hirsutism is the growth of excess terminal hair on the face, chest, linea alba, lower back, buttocks, and anterior thighs in women.

title: Cellulitis - acute
content: Cellulitis is an acute bacterial infection of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.It is acute onset of red, painful, hot, swollen, and tender skin

title: Vitamin D deficiency in children
content: Vitamin D is a fat soluble vitamin that regulates calcium and phosphate homeostasis and is therefore vital for musculoskeletal health.

title: Cough - acute with chest signs in children
content: An upper respiratory tract infection should be considered in a child with a cough, symptoms and signs of infection, and a clear chest on examination.

title: Bone and soft tissue sarcoma - recognition and referral
content: Bone sarcoma is seen in both sexes, and is one of the most common cancers in children, teenagers and young people.

title: Leg cramps
content: A cramp is a transient, involuntary episode of pain, usually sustained for several minutes (up to 10 minutes), in which muscle(s) go into spasm.

title: Baker's cyst
content: Baker's cysts (also known as popliteal cysts) are not true cysts. They are a distension of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa behind the knee.

title: Brain and central nervous system cancers - recognition and referral
content: Around 9000 new primary brain and central nervous system cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK.

title: Corticosteroids - inhaled
content: Corticosteroids are synthetic analogues of hormones produced by the adrenal cortex.Inhaled corticosteroids are glucocorticoids

title: Crohn's disease
content: Crohn's disease is a chronic, relapsing-remitting, non-infectious inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract

title: Corticosteroids - oral
content: Corticosteroids are synthetic analogues of hormones produced by the adrenal cortex.

title: Food allergy
content: Food allergy is an adverse immune response to a food.

title: Cervical screening
content: Cervical screening aims to reduce the incidence of, and mortality from, cervical cancer by systematic, quality assured population-based screening

title: Palliative care - dyspnoea
content: Breathlessness is an objective observable sign, whereas dyspnoea is a subjective described symptoms of difficulty in breathing.

title: Urticaria
content: Urticaria is a superficial swelling of the skin (epidermis and mucous membranes) that results in a red, raised, itchy rash.

title: Pityriasis rosea
content: Pityriasis rosea is a skin rash that is characterized by distinctive scaly, erythematous lesions.

title: Acne vulgaris
content: Acne vulgaris is a chronic skin condition in which blockage or inflammation of the hair follicles and accompanying sebaceous glands

title: Vitamin D deficiency in adults - treatment and prevention
content: Vitamin D is a fat soluble vitamin that regulates calcium and phosphate homeostasis and is therefore vital for musculoskeletal health.

title: Autism in adults
content: Autism spectrum disorder is evidenced by difficulties in social interaction, communication, stereotypic behaviours, resistance to change, or restricted interests.

title: Depression - antenatal and postnatal
content: Depression refers to a range of mental conditions characterized by persistent low mood, absence of positive affect

title: Lyme disease
content: Lyme disease is an infection caused by bacteria called Borrelia burgdorferi, which are transmitted to humans following a bite from an infected tick.

title: Chlamydia - uncomplicated genital
content: Genital chlamydia infection is the most common sexually transmitted bacterial infection in the UK.In men, it infects the urethra.

title: Child maltreatment - recognition and management
content: Child maltreatment includes any type of abuse or neglect of a child/young person caused by inflicting harm or by failing to act to prevent harm.

title: Urinary tract infection (lower) - women
content: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is usually caused by bacteria from the gastrointestinal tract, most commonlyEscherichia coli.

title: Dental abscess
content: A dental abscess is a localized collection of pus in the teeth, supporting structures of the teeth, or gums.

title: Carbon monoxide poisoning
content: Carbon monoxide is a colourless, odourless, tasteless gas produced by incomplete combustion of organic material.

title: Vaginal discharge
content: Normal physiological vaginal discharge changes with the menstrual cycle.

title: Dyspepsia - proven GORD
content: The term 'dyspepsia' is used to describe a complex of upper gastrointestinal tract symptoms

title: Macular degeneration - age-related
content: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the term applied to changes, which occur in the central area of the retina.

title: GORD in children
content: Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD) in children is the presence of troublesome symptoms (for example, discomfort or pain)

title: Bowel screening
content: The NHS Bowel Cancer Screening Programme aims to detect bowel cancer at an early stage.

title: Diarrhoea - adult's assessment
content: Diarrhoea is the abnormal passing of loose or liquid stools, with increased frequency and/or increased volume.

title: Contraception - progestogen-only methods
content: The progestogen-only method of contraception includes the progestogen-only pill (POP), the progestogen-only implant, and the progestogen-only injectable.

title: Meibomian cyst (chalazion)
content: A meibomian cyst (also known as a chalazion) is a sterile, chronic, inflammatory granuloma caused by the obstruction of a meibomian gland.

title: Diabetes - type 1
content: Diabetes mellitus is a group of metabolic disorders characterized by persistent hyperglycaemia (random plasma glucose more than 11 mmol/L).

title: Restless legs syndrome
content: Restless legs syndrome (RLS) is a neurological disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move the limbs (usually the legs)

title: Vitiligo
content: Vitiligo is an acquired, chronic depigmentation disorder characterized by white patches on the skin.

title: Pruritus ani
content: Pruritus ani is a skin condition characterized by the sensation of perianal itching or burning.

title: Nausea/vomiting in pregnancy
content: The majority of women vomit or feel nauseated in early pregnancy. Symptoms usually begin between the fourth and seventh weeks of gestation

title: Roundworm
content: The common human roundworm is a nematode called Ascaris lumbricoides.Infestation occurs when eggs in contaminated food, soil, or water are ingested

title: Headache - medication overuse
content: Medication overuse headache results from regular overuse of headache medication such as ergotamine, triptans, opioids, or other analgesics

title: Bipolar disorder
content: Bipolar disorder is a serious mental illness, that usually characterized by both episodes of depressed mood and episodes of elation

title: Insulin therapy in type 2 diabetes
content: Insulin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by pancreatic beta-cells.The role of insulin is to lower blood glucose to prevent hyperglycaemia

title: Cirrhosis
content: Cirrhosis is a progressive fibrotic nodular liver disease

title: Immunizations - childhood
content: Healthy children should receive vaccines to prevent disease according to the ages stated by the Childhood Immunization Programme.

title: Neck pain - cervical radiculopathy
content: Cervical radiculopathy is usually due to compression or injury to a nerve root in the cervical spine.

title: Hypercalcaemia
content: Hypercalcaemia can be defined as a serum calcium concentration of 2.65 mmol/L (or higher) on two occasions

title: Measles
content: Measles is a highly contagious airborne infection caused by a morbillivirus of the paramyxovirus family.

title: Palliative care - general issues
content: Palliative care is defined as the active holistic care of people with advanced, progressive illness.

title: Migraine
content: Migraine is a primary episodic headache disorder. It is characterized by severe headaches with symptoms such as photophobia, nausea and vomiting

title: Mastitis and breast abscess
content: Mastitis is a painful inflammatory condition of the breast which may or may not be accompanied by infection. It is usually associated with lactation

title: Hypertension - not diabetic
content: Hypertension is persistently raised arterial blood pressure (BP). It is one of several risk factors for diseases

title: Mumps
content: Mumps is a moderate-to-highly contagious acute viral infection caused by a paramyxovirus, and spread by direct contact with saliva.

title: Diarrhoea - prevention and advice for travellers
content: Travellers' diarrhoea is a clinical syndrome associated with contaminated food or water, that occurs during or shortly after travel

title: Polycystic ovary syndrome
content: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a complex endocrine disorder with clinical features that include hirsutism and acne (due to excess androgens)

title: Giant cell arteritis
content: Giant cell arteritis is a type of chronic vasculitis characterized by granulomatous inflammation in the walls of medium and large arteries.

title: Immunizations - seasonal influenza
content: Influenza is an acute viral infection of the respiratory tract. Influenza types A and B are responsible for most clinical illness in the UK.

title: Urinary tract infection (lower) - men
content: Urinary tract infection (UTI) is infection of any part of the urinary tract, usually by bacteria.

title: Febrile seizure
content: A febrile seizure is a seizure associated with fever caused by infection or inflammation outside the central nervous system

title: Poisoning or overdose
content: Poisoning denotes exposure to a substance that is dangerous to health or life. This may be a drug, household product, industrial chemical, plant or animal product

title: Amenorrhoea
content: Amenorrhoea is the absence or cessation of menses. It may be physiological, pathological, or iatrogenic.

title: Trichomoniasis
content: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis.

title: Healthcare-associated infections
content: A healthcare-associated infection develops as a direct result of healthcare interventions, e.g. medical, surgical treatment, or direct contact with a healthcare setting.

title: Falls - risk assessment
content: A fall is defined as an unintentional/unexpected loss of balance resulting in coming to rest on the floor, the ground, or an object below knee level.

title: Insect bites and stings
content: Insects bite by puncturing the skin with piercing mouthparts (for example mosquitos and bedbugs) or by lacerating the skin

title: Cholecystitis - acute
content: Acute cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, the most common cause of which is gallstones.

title: Cataracts
content: A cataract is an opacity (cloudy area) that forms within the lens of an eye which can reduce the transparency of the lens.

title: Back pain - low (without radiculopathy)
content: Low back pain affects the lumbosacral area of the back, between the bottom of the ribs and the top of the legs.

title: Morton's neuroma
content: Morton's neuroma is a benign fibrotic thickening of a plantar interdigital nerve that is a response to irritation.

title: Bell's palsy
content: Bell's palsy is an acute, unilateral, idiopathic, facial nerve paralysis. The paralysis also affects the eyelids, causing an impairment of blinking.

title: Learning disabilities
content: Lower intellectual ability and social functioning  < age 18

title: Contraception - emergency
content: Emergency contraception (EC) is an intervention aimed at preventing unintended pregnancy after unprotected sexual intercourse (UPSI) or contraceptive

title: Urethritis - male
content: Urethritis (inflammation of the urethra) is usually (but not always) caused by a sexually transmitted infection (STI).

title: Hyperhidrosis
content: Hyperhidrosis, or excessive sweating, can be classified by location (focal or generalized) and by the presence of an underlying cause

title: Incontinence - urinary, in women
content: Urinary incontinence is defined as any involuntary leakage of urine. The main types are:Stress urinary incontinence.Urgency urinary incontinence.

title: Tinnitus
content: Tinnitus is the perception of sound in the absence of sound from the external environment.

title: Renal or ureteric colic - acute
content: The term renal colic is generally used to describe an acute and severe loin pain caused by a urinary stone obstructing the flow of urine.

title: Sore throat - acute
content: The term 'sore throat' describes the symptom of pain at the back of the mouth.

title: Erectile dysfunction
content: Erectile dysfunction is the persistent inability to attain and maintain an erection sufficient to permit satisfactory sexual performance.

title: Undescended testes
content: Undescended testes or cryptorchidism is defined as the incomplete descent of one or both testes and absence from the scrotum.

title: Bruising
content: A bruise is a haematoma which forms due to bleeding under intact skin into subcutaneous tissue, due to vascular damage or injury

title: Deep vein thrombosis
content: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the formation of a thrombus in a deep vein, usually in the legs, which partially or completely obstructs blood flow

title: Osteoporosis - prevention of fragility fractures
content: Osteoporosis is a disease characterized by low bone mass and structural deterioration of bone tissue, with a consequent increase in bone fragility

title: Chest pain
content: Chest pain refers to pain in the thorax. It can be classified by:Cause (such as cardiac or non-cardiac).

title: Antiplatelet treatment
content: Antiplatelet treatment prevents the formation of blood clots by preventing platelet aggregation.

title: Alcohol - problem drinking
content: An alcohol problem is categorized depending on the level and pattern of alcohol consumption.

title: LUTS in men
content: Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) in men can be caused by:Structural or functional abnormalities in one or more parts of the lower urinary tract

title: Knee pain - assessment
content: Knee pain is a common condition, particularly in older people.Possible causes include osteoarthritis of the knee, injuries

title: Aphthous ulcer
content: Aphthous ulcers are painful, clearly defined, round or ovoid, shallow ulcers that are confined to the mouth and not associated with systemic disease

title: Whooping cough
content: Whooping cough, also known as pertussis, is a highly infectious disease caused by the bacterium Bordetella pertussis.

title: Contraception - combined hormonal methods
content: There are three types of combined hormonal contraceptives (CHCs): oral contraceptives, transdermal patch, and vaginal ring.

title: Infertility
content: Infertility is the inability to conceive. A couple is regarded as infertile if, after regular sexual intercourse, they have not conceived in 1 year.

title: Dyspepsia - unidentified cause
content: The term 'dyspepsia' is used to describe a complex of upper gastrointestinal tract symptoms

title: Parkinson's disease
content: Parkinson's disease is a chronic, progressive neurodegenerative condition resulting from loss of the dopamine-containing cells of the substantia nigra

title: Syphilis
content: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the spirochete bacterium, Treponema pallidum.

title: Polymyalgia rheumatica
content: Polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) is an inflammatory condition, characterized by aching and morning stiffness in the neck, shoulder, and pelvic girdle.

title: Gastrointestinal tract (upper) cancers - recognition and referral
content: Oesophageal cancer - over 8,000 new oesophageal cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK.

title: Chronic kidney disease
content: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) is an abnormality of kidney function or structure that is present for more than 3 months, with implications for health

title: Bacterial vaginosis
content: Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by an overgrowth of predominantly anaerobic organisms and a loss of lactobacilli.

title: Coeliac disease
content: Coeliac disease is an autoimmune disorder in which a heightened immunological response to peptides derived from gluten proteins

title: Threadworm
content: Threadworm or pinworm (Enterobius vermicularis) is a parasitic worm which infests the intestines of humans.

title: Candida - oral
content: Candida is a yeast-like fungus which is part of the normal commensal flora of the human gastrointestinal tract.

title: Endometriosis
content: Endometriosis is the presence of tissue resembling endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity

title: Meningitis - bacterial meningitis and meningococcal disease
content: Bacterial meningitis is a life-threatening condition that can affect all ages, but is most common in babies and children.

title: Epilepsy
content: Epileptic seizure is a transient disturbance of consciousness, behaviour, emotion, motor function, or sensation, due to abnormal electrical activity

title: Teething
content: Teething is a normal physiological process in which deciduous teeth (milk teeth or baby teeth) emerge through the gums.

title: Hypertension in pregnancy
content: Several different hypertensive disorders can complicate pregnancy.

title: Gout
content: Gout is a disorder of purine metabolism characterized by a raised uric acid level in the blood (hyperuricaemia) and the deposition of urate crystals

title: Gingivitis and periodontitis
content: Gingivitis is inflammation of the gums.Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis (ANUG) is an acute, atypical, progressive, painful bacterial infection

title: Gallstones
content: A gallstone (cholelithiasis) is a solid deposit that forms within the gallbladder. One or more gallstones may form.

title: Angina
content: Angina is chest pain (or constricting discomfort) caused by an insufficient blood supply to the heart muscle.

title: Addison's disease
content: Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency) is caused by destruction of the adrenal cortex.

title: Burns and scalds
content: A burn is an injury caused by exposure to thermal (heat), chemical, electrical, or radiation energy.

title: Breast cancer - managing FH
content: A family history of breast cancer is one of the strongest risk factors for developing breast cancer, increasing with the number of affected relatives.

title: Nappy rash
content: Nappy rash is an irritant contact dermatitis confined to the nappy area. Colonization with Candida albicans is usual.

title: Influenza - seasonal
content: Influenza is an acute respiratory illness caused by RNA viruses of the family Orthomyxoviridae (influenza viruses).

title: Pityriasis versicolor
content: Pityriasis versicolor (also known as tinea versicolor) is a common fungal infection of the skin that is localized to the stratum corneum.

title: Tuberculosis
content: Tuberculosis (TB) is an infection caused by bacteria of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex.

title: Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain
content: For adults, a stepwise strategy for managing mild-to-moderate pain is recommended

title: Melanoma and pigmented lesions
content: A melanoma of the skin is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes in the skin.

title: Pelvic inflammatory disease
content: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a general term for infection of the upper genital tract.PID is usually due to a sexually transmitted disease

title: Hiccups
content: Hiccups involve an involuntary (reflex) diaphragmatic contraction, causing sudden inspiration.

title: Osgood-Schlatter disease
content: Osgood–Schlatter disease is a disorder of the tibial tuberosity caused by multiple small avulsion fractures within the ossification centre

title: Lacerations
content: A laceration is a tearing or splitting of the skin commonly caused by blunt trauma, or an incision caused by a sharp object, such as a knife.

title: Alopecia, androgenetic - male
content: Androgenetic alopeciadescribes a distinctive pattern of hair loss, which may occur in genetically predisposed men

title: Varicose veins
content: Varicose veins are tortuous, dilated, superficial leg veins.

title: Eating disorders
content: The main types of eating disorders are:Anorexia nervosa — the person maintains a low body weight as a result of a preoccupation with weight

title: Psoriasis
content: Psoriasis is a systemic, immune-mediated, inflammatory skin disease which typically has a chronic relapsing-remitting course

title: Self-harm
content: Self-harm refers to an intentional act of self-poisoning or self-injury, irrespective of the motivation or apparent purpose of the act

title: Breastfeeding problems
content: The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends exclusive breastfeeding until an infant is at least 6 months of age

title: Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis)
content: Glandular fever (infectious mononucleosis) is an infectious disease caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) which is a member of the human herpes virus

title: Insomnia
content: Insomnia is difficulty in getting to sleep, difficulty staying asleep, early wakening, or non-restorative sleep

title: Osteoarthritis
content: Osteoarthritis is defined as a disorder of synovial joints, that is characterized by focal areas of damage to the articular cartilage

title: MRSA in primary care
content: Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that is usually commensal, neither harming nor benefiting the host.

title: Cholesteatoma
content: A cholesteatoma is an abnormal sac of keratinizing squamous epithelium and accumulation of keratin within the middle ear or mastoid air cell spaces

title: Feverish children - management
content: A child is considered to have a fever if his or her temperature is 38°C or higher.

title: Ectopic pregnancy
content: An ectopic pregnancy develops outside the uterine cavity with most occurring in the fallopian tubes.

title: DMARDs
content: Disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are a class of drugs, which are designed to influence the course of a disease

title: Anaemia - B12 and folate deficiency
content: Deficiency of vitamin B12 or folate is the most common cause of megaloblastic anaemia.

title: Sickle cell disease
content: Sickle cell disease encompasses a group of inherited conditions which have the inheritance of sickle haemoglobin in common.

title: Obesity
content: The terms 'overweight' and 'obesity' are used to describe excess body fat.

title: Bedwetting (enuresis)
content: Bedwetting is involuntary wetting during sleep, without any inherent suggestion of frequency or pathophysiology.

title: Smoking cessation
content: Tobacco is smoked to obtain nicotine, principally to relieve symptoms of nicotine withdrawal.

title: Dysmenorrhoea
content: Dysmenorrhoea is painful cramping, usually in the lower abdomen, occurring shortly before or during menstruation, or both.

title: Fungal nail infection
content: Fungal nail infection (onychomycosis) can involve the nail plate, nail bed, and/or the root of the nail. It affects toenails more frequently than the

title: Multiple myeloma
content: Multiple myeloma is a progressive malignant disease of abnormal plasma cells in the bone marrow and abnormal monoclonal immunoglobulins

title: Feverish children - risk assessment
content: A child is considered to have a fever if his or her temperature is 38°C or higher.

title: Vestibular neuronitis
content: Vestibular neuronitis (sometimes called vestibular neuritis) is a disorder characterised by acute, isolated, spontaneous, and prolonged vertigo

title: Bunions
content: A bunion is a deformity which occurs when the great toe moves towards the second toe (and may sometimes overlie it).

title: Anticoagulation - oral
content: There are five oral anticoagulants licensed for use in the UK: warfarin, apixaban, dabigatran, edoxaban and rivaroxaban.

title: Rosacea - acne
content: Acne rosacea is a chronic relapsing skin condition affecting the face, characterized by episodes of facial flushing, erythema, telangiectasia.

title: Vertigo
content: Vertigo is a symptom, not a diagnosis. It refers to a false sensation of movement (spinning or rotation) of the person or their surroundings

title: Dupuytren's disease
content: Dupuytren's disease is a benign, progressive fibroproliferative condition of the hand. It causes the bands of connective tissue in the palm to thicken

title: Rheumatoid arthritis
content: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease.RA typically presents as inflammatory arthritis affecting the small joints of the hands

title: Pancreatitis - chronic
content: Chronic pancreatitis is a chronic, irreversible, inflammation and/or fibrosis of the pancreas

title: Scabies
content: Scabies is an intensely itchy skin infestation caused by the human parasite Sarcoptes scabiei. A person with scabies has an average of 10–15 mites.

title: Skin cancers - recognition and referral
content: Melanoma of the skin - just over 13,000 new melanomas are diagnosed each year in the UK.

title: Diabetes - type 2
content: Diabetes mellitus is a group of metabolic disorders characterized by persistent hyperglycaemia (HbA1c more than 48 mmol/mol [6.5%]

title: Dyspepsia - pregnancy-associated
content: Dyspepsia in pregnancy is commonly due to gastro-oesophageal reflux, thought to involve a combination of mechanical and hormonal factors.

title: Lipid modification - CVD prevention
content: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is an umbrella term for diseases that involve the heart, blood vessels, or both, caused by atherosclerosis

title: Palliative care - oral
content: Common oral problems in palliative care include dry mouth, painful mouth, halitosis, alteration of taste, and excessive salivation.

title: Neck lump
content: There are multiple possible causes of neck lumps, including: skin infections, lymphadenopathy, tumours, salivary glands, congenital lumps

title: Pancreatitis - acute
content: Acute pancreatitis is an acute inflammatory process of the pancreas with varying involvement of local tissues or more remote organ systems.

title: Trigeminal neuralgia
content: Trigeminal neuralgia occurs in the distribution of one or more branches of the fifth (trigeminal) cranial nerve.

title: Autism in children
content: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a lifelong condition,which significantly limits or impairs the activities of daily life

title: Faltering growth
content: Low weight or low weight gain in children

title: Peripheral arterial disease
content: The term peripheral arterial disease is a narrowing or occlusion of the peripheral arteries affecting the blood supply to the lower limbs.

title: Blackouts
content: A blackout is a transient loss of consciousness.

title: Raynaud's phenomenon
content: Raynaud's phenomenon is episodic vasospasm of the arteries in the extremities.

title: Antenatal care - uncomplicated pregnancy
content: A woman with an uncomplicated pregnancy is usually managed in the community by a midwife.

title: Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral
content: Ovarian cancer - Over 7,000 new ovarian cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK.

title: Cervical cancer and HPV
content: Types of cervical cancer include:Squamous cell carcinoma and Cervical adenocarcinoma

title: Head lice
content: Head lice (Pediculus humanus capitis) are parasitic insects that infest the hairs of the human head and feed on blood from the scalp.

title: Retinal detachment
content: Retinal detachment refers to the separation of the inner neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium.

title: Scrotal swellings
content: Common, or important causes of scrotal swelling include:Testicular cancer.Squamous cell carcinoma of the scrotum.Testicular torsion

title: Atrial fibrillation
content: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is an arrhythmia. It results from irregular, disorganized electrical activity in the atria, leading to irregular ventricular rhythm

title: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
content: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a treatable (but not curable) and largely preventable lung disease.

title: Breast screening
content: One in nine women will develop breast cancer, and it is more common in women over the age of 50 years.

title: Neck pain - whiplash injury
content: Acute whiplash injury follows sudden or excessive hyperextension, hyperflexion, or rotation of the neck affecting the soft tissues.

title: Prostatitis - acute
content: Acute bacterial prostatitis is a potentially serious non-sexually transmitted bacterial infection of the prostate

title: Prostatitis - chronic
content: Chronic prostatitis is characterized by at least 3 months of pain in the perineum or pelvic floor, often associated with lower urinary tract symptoms

title: Venous eczema and lipodermatosclerosis
content: Venous skin changes usually occur on the lower legs and are often bilateral,They vary, depending on the severity.

title: Compression stockings
content: Compression stockings are useful for treating conditions associated with chronic venous insufficiency, including venous ulcers, varicose veins

title: Balanitis
content: Balanitis is inflammation of the glans penis and often the foreskin. It can be acute, chronic, or recurrent.

title: Hypothyroidism
content: Hypothyroidism is the clinical result of impaired production of thyroid hormones (thyroxine [T4] and tri-iodothyronine [T3]).

title: Conjunctivitis - infective
content: Infective conjunctivitis is inflammation of the conjunctiva due to viral, bacterial or parasitic infection.

title: Dermatitis - contact
content: Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction (dermatitis) that occurs in response to an external stimulus acting as either an irritant

title: Alopecia, androgenetic - female
content: Androgenetic alopecia (or female pattern hair loss) describes a distinctive pattern of hair loss, which may occur in genetically predisposed women

title: Diverticular disease
content: Diverticula are sac-like protrusions of mucosa through the muscular wall of the colon, which occur in the sigmoid colon

title: Haematological cancers - recognition and referral
content: Leukaemia Symptoms include pallor, bruising and infection.

title: Gastrointestinal tract (lower) cancers - recognition and referral
content: Colorectal cancer - around 40,000 new colorectal cancers are diagnosed each year in the UK, up to a quarter of these following screening.

title: Breast cancer - recognition and referral
content: Approximately 50,000 new cases of breast cancer are diagnosed each year in the UK, around a quarter of which through screening mammography.

title: Shoulder pain
content: Causes of pain arising from the shoulder include:Rotator cuff disorders.Frozen shoulder.Instability disorders.

title: Gastroenteritis
content: Gastroenteritis is a transient disorder due to enteric infection with viruses, bacteria, or protozoa.

title: Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome
content: Obstructive sleep apnoea/hypopnoea syndrome (OSAHS) is the coexistence of excessive daytime sleepiness with irregular breathing at night.

title: Constipation
content: Constipation is a symptom-based disorder which describes defecation that is unsatisfactory because of infrequent stools, difficulty passing stools

title: Neck pain - acute torticollis
content: Torticollis, or wry neck, is a twisted neck. Acute torticollis is thought to be due to minor local musculoskeletal irritation causing pain and spasm

title: Scarlet fever
content: Scarlet fever is a notifiable infectious disease caused by toxin-producing strains of the group A streptococcus bacterium (Streptococcus pyogenes).

title: Contraception - barrier methods and spermicides
content: Barrier methods of contraception include:Male and female condoms.Diaphragms and caps.Spermicides.

title: CVD risk assessment and management
content: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a significant cause of mortality and morbidity, accounting for almost a third of all deaths in the UK.

title: Premenstrual syndrome
content: Premenstrual syndrome is a condition in which distressing physical, behavioural, and psychological symptoms, occur in the 2nd half of the menstrual cycle.

title: Pilonidal sinus disease
content: Pilonidal sinus disease is a skin disorder usually found in the midline of the natal cleft.

title: Pruritus vulvae
content: Pruritus vulvae is itching of the vulva (which includes the mons pubis, labia majora, labia minora, clitoris, perineum, urethra and vagina

title: Menopause
content: Menopause is a biological stage in a woman's life when menstruation ceases permanently due to the loss of ovarian follicular activity.

title: Acute childhood limp
content: The term limp refers to an abnormal gait pattern usually caused by pain, weakness, or deformity.

title: Hand foot and mouth disease
content: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness characterized by vesicular eruptions in the mouth and papulovesicular skin lesions

title: Whitlow (staphylococcal and herpetic)
content: Staphylococcal whitlow is a closed-space infection of the distal finger pulp.

title: Sprains and strains
content: A sprain is a stretch and/or tear of a ligament caused by applying abnormal or excessive force to a joint.

title: Cough
content: Cough is a reflex response to airway irritation. It is triggered by stimulation of airway cough receptors

title: Adverse drug reactions
content: An adverse drug reaction (ADR) is an unwanted or harmful reaction which occurs after administration of a drug or drugs.

title: Malaria prophylaxis
content: Prophylaxis used depends on the area to be visited, the age of the person, contraindications to specific drugs in people with co-morbidities, and patient preference.

title: Psychosis and schizophrenia
content: Psychosis is a disordered mental state characterized principally by positive symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, and thought disorder.

title: Polycythaemia/erythrocytosis
content: Erythrocytosis is an abnormally high haematocrit and haemoglobin concentration.

title: Heart failure - chronic
content: Heart failure is a complex syndrome in which the ability of the heart to maintain the circulation of blood

title: Anaemia - iron deficiency
content: Iron deficiency occurs when the body's iron demand is not met by iron absorption from the diet.

title: Halitosis
content: Halitosis (bad breath) is a general term that describes an unpleasant odour in the breath, regardless of the cause of the odour.

title: Corticosteroids - topical (skin), nose, and eyes
content: Corticosteroids are synthetic analogues of the natural hormones that are produced by the adrenal cortex.

title: Insulin therapy in type 1 diabetes
content: Insulin is a polypeptide hormone secreted by pancreatic beta-cells.The role of insulin is to lower blood glucose to prevent hyperglycaemia
